05/19/2022 Preliminary Findings Provided
ALLEGATION: While attending school at the facility, two youth requested
to use the bathroom and engaged in sexual acts in the male bathroom.
It is unknown who was supervising the youth at this time.
INVESTIGATION:
On 05/12/2022 the special investigation was initiated at the facility. A meeting was
held with the Chief Administrator. It was confirmed that the allegations are relevant
to the non-secure program. The Chief Administrator advised that Staff A was on
shift for this day. I was also informed that Youth B is currently COVID positive, and
that Youth A was also tested, but results were negative. I was also advised that
while in school, females and males are in separate classrooms. The Chief
Administrator reported that it was his understanding that the youth asked to go to the
restroom at different times yet ended up in the male restroom together. A tour of the
school and the bathroom area was completed. A request was also made for a copy
of the supervision policy and any incident reports associated with the incident.
On 05/13/2022 I received an email with copies of the supervision policy and hall
monitor policy for the school. Both polices were reviewed. The hall monitor policy
specifically indicated that hall monitor staff are expected to check the restroom after
each use and that Youth Specialist must monitor the halls and classrooms from a
standing/walking position when assigned to hall monitor duty. The supervision
policy indicated that staff will maintain line of sight at all times and provide vigilant
supervision of the youth.
2

On 05/19/2022 Staff A was interviewed at Children’s Village. He advised that he is a
17-year employee and has one incident of discipline in his employee file. Staff A
advised that policy identifies a time for boys to go to the restroom and for girls to go
to the restroom. Boys are supposed to go during 2nd and 5th hour and girls are to go
during 1st and 6th hour. Staff A confirmed that this did not occur. Staff A also
confirmed that staff are required to unlock the restrooms for residents to enter. Staff
A reported that Youth B first came out and requested to go to the restroom. He
recalls that he did ask her why she was out during this time (as it was not time for
female residents). Youth B responded that she must go to the restroom, and he
observed a sanitary napkin in her hand, so he let her in. He then reported that
moments later Youth A came out of his classroom and requested entry to the
restroom, and he let him in. Staff A admitted that after both residents were in the
restroom, he returned to a bench at the entrance of the facility and sat down. Staff A
indicated that he does not recall the youth coming out of the restroom and admitted
that he did not check the restrooms as required by policy.
On 05/19/2022 an interview of Youth A occurred at Children’s Village. Youth A was
initially unwilling to answer any questions regarding the incident. He indicated that
the police had been to talk with him, and he thought this was “all over”. I advised
him that I was attempting to determine if the agency had violated any of the licensing
rules that are in place. Youth A confirmed that Staff A was on staff the date of the
incident and that he let both him and Youth B into the restroom. Youth A then
indicated that Staff A failed to continue to provide monitoring and returned to “the
bench” to sit down. He stated that the normal staff person always continues to
monitor, but Staff A did not.
On 05/19/2022 an attempt was made to interview Youth B. I was unable to interview
her as she had returned to quarantine status due to COVID exposure. Additional
attempts to interview Youth B were not made as non-compliance with the licensing
rules had been confirmed.
On 05/19/2022 preliminary findings of the investigation were provided to the Chief
Administrator.
Documentation reviewed for this investigation includes the following:
• Children’s Village Supervision Policy
• Children’s Village Hall Monitor Policy
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
3

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: At the conclusion of the investigation, there was sufficient
evidence to support non-compliance by the agency with
licensing rule R 400.4109 (1) (c). Both Staff A and Youth A
reported that line of sight supervision was not maintained.
Specifically Staff A admitted to returning to a bench area to sit
down and failing to monitor youth that were in the restroom.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violation.
